content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: This company is using AI to give people American-sounding accents
entries.snippet:
Krisp, a company known for its noise cancellation app, has launched a new AI-powered tool that modifies a speaker’s accent to sound American in real time. Integrated into Krisp's existing desktop app, the feature functions as a virtual microphone compatible with video conferencing platforms like Zoom, Microsoft Teams, Google Meet, and Webex. The AI Accent Conversion tool introduces a minimal 200ms delay and maintains the user’s natural voice; however, early demos show the output may still sound somewhat robotic.

Initially supporting over 17 Indian dialects, Krisp intends to expand to other accents, including Filipino. The tool was first deployed to call centers before its public beta release. Co-founder Arto Minasyan emphasized that the tool aims to minimize misunderstandings in communication—not to address bias, but to increase efficiency in fast-paced conversations. The service is free for up to 60 minutes daily, with a $15/month business plan for unlimited access. Other companies, like Teleperformance SE, are also exploring AI-driven accent modification, raising concerns about the ethical implications and reliability of such technology, particularly in sensitive contexts like race and identity.

entries.title: AdaSpeech: Adaptive Text to Speech for Custom Voice
OpenAI reveals Voice Engine, but won't yet publicly release the risky AI voice-cloning technology
entries.snippet: OpenAI has unveiled a new technology called Voice Engine, which can clone a person's voice using just 15 seconds of recorded audio. Despite demonstrating its capabilities, OpenAI has chosen not to publicly release the technology due to concerns over potential misuse, particularly during an election year. The company highlighted the risks of producing speech that imitates real people and cited ethical concerns, especially in light of recent incidents involving AI-generated robocalls mimicking political figures. Voice Engine will be tested with early users under strict guidelines: voices must not be used to impersonate individuals without consent, and all AI-generated voices must be disclosed. This move aligns with OpenAI's cautious release strategy previously seen with its video generator, Sora. OpenAI has also filed a trademark for Voice Engine and may enter the broader market of speech recognition and digital voice assistants, potentially positioning itself against competitors like Amazon's Alexa. The Associated Press has a licensing and technology agreement with OpenAI.

entries.title: Holly Herndon's AI Deepfake "Twin" Holly+ Transforms Any Song Into a Holly Herndon Song
entries.snippet:
Holly Herndon, an artist known for integrating AI into music, has unveiled Holly+, an AI deepfake "twin" that transforms any polyphonic audio into a rendition sung in Herndon's voice. This voice instrument is accessible via a website where users can upload songs and receive transformed versions. Herndon emphasizes the importance of balancing artist protection with the creative possibilities of new AI technologies. The project represents a move toward communal voice ownership, acknowledging that vocal expression is inherently shared and interpretative.

Holly+ is managed by a Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO), with profits from licensing and usage funding further development. Additionally, the DAO plans to launch an auction platform to sell officially approved artworks using Holly+ in partnership with Zora protocol’s Auction House. The initiative opens discussions on the future of vocal rights and artistic collaboration in the AI era.

v.title: ConVoice: Real-Time Zero-Shot Voice Style Transfer with Convolutional Network
Voila: Voice-Language Foundation Models for Real-Time Autonomous Interaction and Voice Role-Play

entries.title: "Not just a DAW, a behind-the-scenes music recording partner": Universal Audio's Luna updated with AI-powered tools, including voice control and instrument detection
entries.snippet: Universal Audio has released version 1.9 of its free DAW, Luna, introducing a suite of AI-powered features aimed at improving music recording and production. Launched in 2020 and later made universally available on macOS and Windows, Luna integrates UA's analogue emulations and vintage-style workflows. The Luna 1.9 update adds innovative tools like voice control — allowing hands-free recording through "Hey Luna" (available only on Apple Silicon Macs) — instrument detection, which identifies and color-codes incoming audio tracks, and advanced tempo features. Tempo Listen adjusts the metronome to a musician's performance in real time, while Tempo Detection and Tempo Extraction manage tempo settings for imported files or complex, tempo-shifting recordings. Universal Audio positions Luna as more than just a DAW — it's a creative companion. The update is free for all macOS and Windows users, though some features remain exclusive to the Luna Pro version.

entries.title: AI voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices
entries.snippet:
A recent study published in *PLoS One* reveals that AI-generated "deepfake" voices have become so realistic that the average listener can no longer reliably distinguish them from real human voices. While generic AI voices were correctly identified as artificial 59% of the time, cloned voices—trained on real people's speech—were misclassified as human 58% of the time, showing almost no perceptual difference from the originals. Conducted by researchers at Queen Mary University of London, the study used 80 samples (40 real, 40 AI-generated) and demonstrated that simple, low-cost tools with just four minutes of audio can create highly convincing voice clones.

These findings carry serious ethical and security concerns. Criminals can exploit voice cloning to bypass authentication systems or scam individuals, as illustrated in a case where a woman was tricked into transferring $15,000 after hearing what she believed was her daughter's voice. Deepfake audio also raises risks for misinformation, such as faked political statements or celebrity endorsements used in scams. However, the technology also holds promise for beneficial applications in accessibility, education, and personalized user experiences.

entries.title: World's first AI-powered transformable mic hits the UK market - where to buy
entries.snippet:
The BOYA Magic Mic, the world's first AI-powered transformable microphone, has launched in the UK, priced at £68.20. Designed for content creators like vloggers, podcasters, and influencers, the mic offers four-in-one functionality: clip-on, handheld, desktop, and camera-mounted modes. Weighing just 81.5 grams, it’s lightweight and portable with a sleek case for easy transport.

Key features include advanced AI noise cancellation trained on over 700,000 noise samples, with modes that cut up to -40 dB of background sound in noisy environments or up to -15 dB in quieter settings. It records crystal-clear 48kHz/24-bit audio with an omnidirectional pickup and includes a smart limiter for distortion control and a backup low-volume audio track (-12 dB) for added reliability.

Each transmitter offers 6 hours of use, extended to 30 hours with the charging case, and boasts up to 100 metres of transmission range. It supports phones, cameras, and computers and allows for dual transmitter setups. The BOYA Magic Mic is available via Amazon and the official Boya store.
